review.title: Measuring an Artificial Intelligence System's Performance on a Verbal IQ Test For Young Children
review.abstract: We administered the Verbal IQ (VIQ) part of the Wechsler Preschool and Primary Scale of Intelligence (WPPSI-III) to the ConceptNet 4 AI system. The test questions (e.g., "Why do we shake hands?") were translated into ConceptNet 4 inputs using a combination of the simple natural language processing tools that come with ConceptNet together with short Python programs that we wrote. The question answering used a version of ConceptNet based on spectral methods. The ConceptNet system scored a WPPSI-III VIQ that is average for a four-year-old child, but below average for 5 to 7 year-olds. Large variations among subtests indicate potential areas of improvement. In particular, results were strongest for the Vocabulary and Similarities subtests, intermediate for the Information subtest, and lowest for the Comprehension and Word Reasoning subtests. Comprehension is the subtest most strongly associated with common sense. The large variations among subtests and ordinary common sense strongly suggest that the WPPSI-III VIQ results do not show that "ConceptNet has the verbal abilities a four-year-old." Rather, children's IQ tests offer one objective metric for the evaluation and comparison of AI systems. Also, this work continues previous research on Psychometric AI.

metadata.title: Measuring an Artificial Intelligence System’s Performance on a Verbal IQ Test For Young Children

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: They emphasize that acting sometimes means outperforming humans (e.g., computers have outperformed humans in arithmetic from the beginning, and computers have outperformed humans in chess in recent years). Of course, acting also means performing at least as well as humans in every task. How should we measure performance? Psychometric AI (PAI) [3, 4] (see also, e.g., [8, 9, 38]) argues that for many areas psychometric tests designed for humans are provided ready-made tools. Psychometrics itself is the industry of psychology that published the objective measurement of this work as a 2-page AAAAI 2013, which features late-breaking development posters and in a workshop [29, 30] human skills and traits.

sections.heading: 1.1 Prior Work
sections.text: In fact, most of them will be able to play by the rules.

sections.heading: 1.2 Present Work
sections.text: In this context, it should be noted that this is a very complex and complex matter.

sections.heading: 1.3 Summary of Contributions and Results
sections.text: The main contributions to our work are the following: (1) We show how to use an actual verbal IQ test as a measurement in the effort for psychometric AI. This is important because the IQ test is the psychometric method that is used, if necessary, to give a comprehensive overview of young children. (2) We highlight the strengths and weaknesses of at least one healthy AI knowledge base and highlight focal points for further research. (3) We show how strongly the topics of knowledge representation, common sense, natural language processing and question answers are intertwined. (4) We provide empirical results on the capabilities of ConceptNet as measured by the verbal share of WPPSI-III. A general conclusion of our work is that ConceptNet has a WPSI-III VIQ of an average four-year-old child. As discussed in more detail later, our implementation of algorithms to answer queries was simple.

sections.heading: 4.2 Determining the VIQ Score
sections.text: We rated the WPPSI III sub-tests once with the best-rated answer on each topic and a second time with the best answer out of the five best-rated answers on each topic. We call the former rigorous rating and the latter relaxed. Comparing the rigorous and the relaxed results gives us an indication of the robustness of the results.

In particular, in the late 1950s John McCarthy’s paper “Programs with Common Sense’’ [25] noted that “certain elementary verbal reasoning processes so simple that they can be carried out by any non-feeble minded human have yet to be simulated by machine programs.

’’ Thirty years later, Davis described common sense for an AI system as “common knowledge about the world that is possessed by every schoolchild and the methods for making obvious inferences from this knowledge” and illustrated this definition with an example “easily understood by five-year-old children” [11].

Roughly twenty years after that, in 2008 Rodney Brooks gave a list of challenges for artificial intelligence [5, 27] that included performing with the language capabilities of a 4-year-old child, and the social understanding of an 8-year-old child.
Indeed, this notion goes back at least to Edward Feigenbaum’s knowledge principle [6, 15]: High performance on intellectual tasks is based on a large knowledge base.
Indeed, this notion goes back at least to Edward Feigenbaum’s knowledge principle [6, 15]: High performance on intellectual tasks is based on a large knowledge base.

Therefore, as our initial trial of the WPPSI-III as a PAI instrument, we started out trying to test two systems based on large knowledge bases: ConceptNet/AnalogySpace [16, 17, 37] and Cyc [22], two representative systems that have both been around for some time, and are in the public domain.

Sanghi and Dowe [34] programmed a system that can respond to three types of nonverbal questions They report IQ scores of the program for 12 different “IQ tests,” from various books and websites.
In subsequent articles, Dowe and Hernández-Orallo have argued against this empirical approach [13].
Instead, they advocate a rational approach to measuring the intelligence of an AI system based on theoretical and formal considerations [18].

Turney [38] built a system based on analogies, and was able to use it to obtain reasonably strong results on seven different questions types, including multiple-choice synonym questions from the TOEFL (test of English as a foreign language) and classifying word pairs as either synonyms or antonyms, as well as analogy questions from the SAT.
[40] identified five types of items used in multiple-choice verbal “IQ tests:” Two types of analogies, classification, synonym and antonym items.
The Winograd Schema Challenge [23] is another metric that has been proposed to highlight verbal problems that are easy for humans but appear to be difficult for AI systems.

One of our interests is in large knowledge bases, such as ConceptNet, Cyc, or NELL [7], and such knowledge bases must be usable by computer science researchers (and eventually practitioners) in general, not only by their creators.
The Open Mind Common Sense initiative originally acquired a large common-sense knowledge base from web users [35].
AnalogySpace [36, 37] is a concise version of the ConceptNet knowledge base that its creators say is “designed to facilitate reasoning over” ConceptNet [27].

This reduced-dimension matrix, which is called AnalogySpace, is claimed to give better, more meaningful descriptions of the knowledge [37].
For example “the feature vector for ‘steering wheel’ could have +1 in the position for ‘is part of a car’, +1 for ‘is round’, and −1 for ‘is alive’ ” [37].
We reported on our planned methodology and some preliminary results based only on our own item pool in [28].
The high score on the Similarities subtest may reflect that abstracting categories is a particular goal of the AnalogySpace designer’s use of spectral methods [37].
This result is far below the 9 to 12 grade performance claimed by Evans [14] for his visual analogy program.
Answering why-questions, which make up most of the Comprehension items, is known to be a difficult problem in question answering [24].

The era of knowledge driven AI, resting upon logic, reasoning, and knowledge, appears to have past [10].
Interestingly, each of ConceptNet 4, the recently released ConceptNet 5, Google’s knowledge graph, and the output of NELL [7] have at least some aspects of both paradigms.

metadata.abstractText: We administered the Verbal IQ (VIQ) part of the Wechsler Preschool and Primary Scale of Intelligence (WPPSI-III) to the ConceptNet 4 AI system. The test questions (e.g., “Why do we shake hands?”) were translated into ConceptNet 4 inputs using a combination of the simple natural language processing tools that come with ConceptNet together with short Python programs that we wrote. The question answering used a version of ConceptNet based on spectral methods. The ConceptNet system scored a WPPSI-III VIQ that is average for a four-year-old child, but below average for 5 to 7 year-olds. Large variations among subtests indicate potential areas of improvement. In particular, results were strongest for the Vocabulary and Similarities subtests, intermediate for the Information subtest, and lowest for the Comprehension and Word Reasoning subtests. Comprehension is the subtest most strongly associated with common sense. The large variations among subtests and ordinary common sense strongly suggest that the WPPSI-III VIQ results do not show that “ConceptNet has the verbal abilities a four-year-old.” Rather, children’s IQ tests offer one objective metric for the evaluation and comparison of AI systems. Also, this work continues previous research on Psychometric AI.
